questions.text: A 34-year-old serving soldier of the Indian army presented with explosive outbursts of extreme violence and anger for the last 2 years, which were not directed. Following this act of aggression, he would experience a sense of gratification and relief. The episodes were recurrent and resulted in assaults or destruction of property. The aggression displayed was out of proportion to any perceived provocation, and the individual felt increasing tension or arousal before committing the act. He did not have any feelings of regret, remorse, or guilt about the behaviour. Which is the incorrect statement to arrive at his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The correct diagnosis is Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED), as the patient has sudden, unprovoked, and recurrent violent outbursts that are disproportionate to any stressor, followed by relief but not remorse. His aggression is episodic, with no continuous pattern of antisocial behavior between episodes, ruling out Conduct Disorder or Personality Disorders.

  • Conduct Disorder requires early onset (before 18 years) and involves a pervasive pattern of violating societal norms, including deceit, cruelty, truancy, and deliberate aggression, not just episodic violence.
  • This patient is 34 years old with no reported history of such behavior in childhood/adolescence, making this option invalid.

Intermittent Explosive Disorder:

IED is characterized by discrete episodes of failure to control aggressive impulses, leading to serious assault or destruction of property, which are disproportionate to the stressor and not premeditated.

Clinical Features:

  • Episodes appear rapidly, typically without warning.
  • Behavior is impulsive and not goal-directed.
  • Patients often have poor job and social functioning.
  • Euthymic mood between episodes (vs. Cluster B or bipolar).
  • May report a poor childhood environment (e.g., violence, alcohol abuse).

Treatment:

Combination Therapy is Best:

  • Psychotherapy: CBT, group, and family therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine): reduce impulsivity
    • Mood stabilizers: lithium, valproate, carbamazepine
    • β-blockers: propranolol
    • Antipsychotics (only if other causes have been ruled out)
    • Avoid benzodiazepines: they may worsen disinhibition

Explanation of other options:

The most appropriate diagnosis would be Intermittent explosive disorder due to the episodic nature of outbursts (Option A): IED diagnosis is correct because the outbursts are episodic and impulsive-matches the DSM-5 definition.

Cluster B personality disorders can be ruled out as in them, aggressiveness and impulsivity are present even between the outbursts (Option C): Cluster B personality disorders (like antisocial or borderline) show chronic patterns of aggression and interpersonal instability, not isolated episodes.

Bipolar disorder or psychosis can be ruled out because other symptoms suggestive are absent (Option D): Bipolar disorder or psychosis are ruled out as there are no mood swings, psychotic features, or loss of reality testing seen in this case.

questions.text: A 38-year-old divorced female professor, belonging to the high socio-economic class, was reprimanded many times for charges of shoplifting, which she had started at the age of 22. She would steal only on impulse, not from premeditation, and experienced tension before, and satisfaction after, shoplifting. The stolen items included crayons, spoons, candles, coloured papers, earrings, etc., which she hoarded in her cupboard. What would her diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

This 38-year-old woman shows classic features of kleptomania. It is characterised by a recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects not needed for use or value

Key Features of Kleptomania:

  • Impulse-control disorder: Characterized by repeated failure to resist the urge to steal items not needed for personal use or monetary value.
  • Emotional build-up and relief: Tension builds before the act, followed by pleasure, gratification, or relief immediately after stealing.
  • Nature of stolen items: Objects are usually of little value (e.g., crayons, spoons, candles), often hoarded, discarded, or given away rather than used.
  • No monetary motivation: The person can afford the items; stealing is not for financial gain.
  • Lack of premeditation: Acts are impulsive, not planned, or done to express anger or vengeance.
  • Insight may vary: The person may feel guilt, shame, or depression afterward, but not always.
  • Exclusion criteria: Behavior is not better explained by
    • Conduct disorder
    • Antisocial personality disorder
    • Manic episode
    • Psychotic disorders
  • Onset and course: Usually begins in adolescence or early adulthood; more common in females.
  • Comorbidity: May co-occur with mood disorders, anxiety, eating disorders, or substance use.

Explanation of other options:

Pyromania (Option A): A type of impulse control disorder characterized by repeated, deliberate fire-setting driven by fascination or gratification from fire and its effects. There is typically tension or emotional arousal before the act and pleasure or relief afterward, but no intent to harm for material gain.

Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED) (Option C): IED involves sudden episodes of impulsive, aggressive, or violent behavior that are grossly out of proportion to the situation. These outbursts may include physical assaults or property destruction, but not stealing or hoarding.

Conduct Disorder (Option D): Diagnosed in children and adolescents and is marked by a repetitive pattern of violating social norms and the rights of others. Behaviors include aggression toward people or animals, destruction of property, deceit, theft, and serious rule violations.

questions.text: A 38-year-old divorced female professor, belonging to the high socio-economic class, was reprimanded many times for charges of shoplifting, which she had started at the age of 22. She would steal only on impulse, not from premeditation, and experienced tension before, and satisfaction after, shoplifting. The stolen items included crayons, spoons, candles, coloured papers, earrings, etc., which she hoarded in her cupboard. In the above case, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • The case describes classic features of Kleptomania, an impulse control disorder.
  • In Kleptomania, the act of stealing itself is the goal, not the stolen object.
  • Individuals often have the means to purchase the items and derive no practical benefit from them. The motivation is internal tension and the need to release it, not material gain.

Explanation of other options:

This disorder is categorised under Disruptive and Impulse Control disorders in DSM-5 (Option A): True. According to DSM-5, Kleptomania is classified under Disruptive, Impulse-Control, and Conduct Disorders.

Antisocial personality disorder should be ruled out (Option C): True. Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) can also involve stealing, but in ASPD, it's part of a broader pattern of violating other's rights and norms, often for personal gain, and lacks guilt or internal tension. This must be ruled out when diagnosing Kleptomania.

SSRI and CBT are usually helpful (Option D): True. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) have shown benefit in managing impulse-control disorders like Kleptomania by helping manage urges and associated anxiety.

questions.text: All of the following Disruptive and Impulse control disorders are seen in adults except?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) is typically diagnosed in childhood or adolescence, not in adults.

ODD is a childhood-onset disorder marked by a pattern of negativistic, hostile, and defiant behavior toward authority figures, without serious violations of social norms (unlike conduct disorder).

Core Features (Grouped into 3 Symptom Clusters):

A child must have at least 4 symptoms lasting ≥6 months, with at least one interaction outside of a sibling.

  1. Angry/Irritable Mood:
    • Often loses temper
    • Is touchy or easily annoyed
    • Is angry and resentful
  2. Argumentative/Defiant Behavior:
    • Often argues with authority figures
    • Refuses to comply with rules or requests
    • Deliberately annoys others
    • Blames others for mistakes or misbehavior
  3. Vindictiveness:
    • Is spiteful or vindictive at least twice in the past 6 months

Age of Onset & Course:

  • Can begin by age 3, but typically recognized by 8 years
  • May progress to conduct disorder or antisocial personality disorder, especially if symptoms are severe and persistent

Treatment:

  • First-line: Parent management training, behavior therapy
  • CBT for older children/adolescents
  • Address co-morbidities (ADHD, mood disorders) if present
  • Medication: Not usually required unless for comorbid conditions

Explanation of other options:

Intermittent Explosive Disorder (Option A): Occurs in adults, characterized by episodic, disproportionate aggression, like verbal or physical outbursts.

Kleptomania (Option C): An impulse control disorder in adults where the person steals items they don't need, driven by tension and relieved by the act.

Pyromania (Option D): Involves repeated deliberate fire-setting with increasing tension before the act and relief afterward-seen in adults.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the clinic for evaluation of irritability, negativity, and disobedience by his mother. She complained that he had frequent, prolonged tantrums, triggered by not "getting his way". These tantrums consisted of shouting, cursing, crying, slamming doors, and sometimes throwing books or objects on the floor. Such behaviour of his continued in school as well, and there were frequent complaints from teachers regarding his disobedient behaviour. However, he was academically competent. Which would be the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The diagnosis in this child is Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) because he exhibits a persistent pattern of angry outbursts, defiance, and argumentative behavior toward authority figures both at home and in school. His normal academic performance and absence of attention deficits or social communication problems rule out other neurodevelopmental disorders.

ODD is a childhood-onset disorder marked by a pattern of negativistic, hostile, and defiant behavior toward authority figures, without serious violations of social norms (unlike conduct disorder).

Core Features (Grouped into 3 Symptom Clusters):

A child must have at least 4 symptoms lasting ≥6 months, with at least one interaction outside of a sibling.

  1. Angry/Irritable Mood:
    • Often loses temper
    • Is touchy or easily annoyed
    • Is angry and resentful
  2. Argumentative/Defiant Behavior:
    • Often argues with authority figures
    • Refuses to comply with rules or requests
    • Deliberately annoys others
    • Blames others for mistakes or misbehavior
  3. Vindictiveness:
    • Is spiteful or vindictive at least twice in the past 6 months

Age of Onset & Course:

  • Can begin by age 3, but typically recognized by 8 years
  • May progress to conduct disorder or antisocial personality disorder, especially if symptoms are severe and persistent

Treatment:

  • First-line: Parent management training, behavior therapy
  • CBT for older children/adolescents
  • Address co-morbidities (ADHD, mood disorders) if present
  • Medication: Not usually required unless for comorbid conditions

Explanation of other options:

Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Option B): ADHD features include inattention, impulsivity, and/or hyperactivity. This child shows no evidence of distractibility or hyperactivity - his issue is behavioral defiance, not attention.

Intellectual Disability (Option C): Characterized by deficits in intellectual functioning (reasoning, problem-solving) and adaptive behavior. This child is academically competent, so this diagnosis is inconsistent with his performance.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (Option D): Typically involves communication deficits, restricted interests, and social interaction difficulties. No mention of such traits; the child seems socially interactive but defiant, not socially impaired.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of behavioural disturbances at home, school, and in the community. He exhibits behavioural disturbances like temper tantrums, picking up physical fights frequently, stealing from neighborhood stores, smoking marijuana, bullying his younger siblings, occasionally setting small fires in his house, etc., which began at the age of 6 years. Most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • This boy exhibits a persistent pattern of violating social norms and the rights of others, including aggression, theft, substance use, and property destruction-all hallmark features of Conduct Disorder.
  • The early onset before age 10, combined with behaviors across multiple settings (home, school, and community), supports this diagnosis over other disruptive or neurodevelopmental disorders.

Conduct Disorder is a persistent and repetitive pattern of behavior in children and adolescents that violates societal norms and the basic rights of others.

Core Features:

According to Kaplan and standard diagnostic criteria, the child must show at least 3 of the following behaviors in the past 12 months, with at least one in the past 6 months:

  • Aggression to people and animals:
    • Bullying, threatening, or intimidating others
    • Initiating physical fights
    • Using weapons
    • Cruelty to people or animals
    • Stealing while confronting a victim (e.g., mugging)
    • Forcing someone into sexual activity
  • Destruction of property:
    • Deliberate fire setting with intent to cause damage (pyromania excluded)
    • Deliberately destroying other's property
  • Deceitfulness or theft:
    • Breaking into a house, building, or car
    • Lying to obtain goods/favors or to avoid obligations
    • Stealing items without confronting a victim (e.g., shoplifting)
  • Serious violations of rules:
    • Staying out at night despite parental prohibitions (before age 13)
    • Running away from home overnight at least twice
    • Often truant from school (before age 13)

Explanation of other options:

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) (Option A): ODD is marked by negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behavior toward authority figures, but it does not include aggression toward people or animals, destruction of property, or serious violations of social norms. In this case, the child's physical aggression, fire-setting, theft, and substance use go far beyond ODD

Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED) (Option C): IED is characterized by brief, sudden outbursts of aggression that are out of proportion to the situation, with euthymic mood between episodes. The behavior here is not episodic but persistent and patterned, involving multiple types of rule violations, not consistent with IED.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (Option D): ASD involves deficits in social communication and restricted, repetitive behaviors, but not deliberate aggression, deceit, or rule-breaking. This child's behavior suggests intentional rule violation rather than social skill deficits or developmental delay.

choices.text: Antisocial personality disorder cannot be diagnosed as age is less than 18 years
Unplanned pregnancies and, chaotic home environment are usual contributors to this condition
ADHD is rarely found comorbid with this condition
Age of onset is earlier in boys than in girls

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of behavioural disturbances at home, school, and in the community. He exhibits behavioural disturbances like temper tantrums, picking up physical fights frequently, stealing from the neighborhood store, smoking marijuana, bullying his younger siblings, occasionally setting small fires in his house, etc. In the above case, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

ADHD is commonly comorbid with Conduct Disorder (CD). These two conditions often coexist, and when they do, they are associated with worse prognosis, greater impulsivity, and more severe aggression.

Explanation of other options:

Antisocial personality disorder cannot be diagnosed if the age is less than 18 years (Option A): True. Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) can only be diagnosed after 18 years of age. Before that, similar behavioral patterns were diagnosed as Conduct Disorder.

Unplanned pregnancies, chaotic home environments are usual contributors to this condition (Option B): True. Environmental stressors like unplanned pregnancies, chaotic home life, harsh parenting, and family conflict are established risk factors for the development of Conduct Disorder.

Age of onset is earlier in boys than in girls (Option D): True. The age of onset for CD is typically earlier in boys (around 10-12 years) than in girls (usually 14-16 years). Boys also tend to show more overt aggression, while girls may show more covert behaviors.

choices.text: Lack of remorse/ guilt for their actions

questions.text: All of the following themes are usually present in children with conduct disorder except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Communication skills are not typically impaired in children with Conduct Disorder (CD).

Many children with CD can be socially articulate and manipulative. The problem lies in behavior and emotional regulation, not verbal ability or communication per se.

Explanation of other options:

Lack of remorse/guilt for their actions (Option A): True. Children with CD often show a lack of remorse or guilt, even after hurting others or breaking rules. This is a key emotional feature of the disorder.

Lack of empathy for others (Option B): True. A callous lack of empathy is commonly observed. These children may be indifferent to other's pain or suffering.

Lack of social emotions (Option C): True. CD is associated with reduced prosocial emotions, also termed "limited prosocial emotions" in DSM-5, including a lack of guilt, empathy, concern about performance, and shallow affect.
